This was followed by *Viaje del Parnaso*, *Eight Comedies and Eight New Interludes*, and *Los trabajos de Persiles y Sigismunda*, completed just before his death, and published posthumously in January 1617.


Cervantes was rediscovered by English writers in the mid-18th century. The literary editor John Bowle argued that Cervantes was as significant as any of the Greek and Roman authors then popular, and published an annotated edition in 1781. Now viewed as a significant work, at the time it proved a failure.[66] However, *Don Quixote* has been translated into all major languages, in 700 editions. Mexican author Carlos Fuentes suggested that Cervantes and his contemporary William Shakespeare form part of a narrative tradition that includes Homer, Dante, Defoe, Dickens, Balzac, and Joyce.[67]

His first significant novel, titled *La Galatea*, was published in 1585, but he continued to work as a purchasing agent, and later as a government tax collector. Part One of *Don Quixote* was published in 1605, and Part Two in 1615. Dickens was the most popular novelist of his time,[215] and remains one of the best-known and most-read of English authors. His works have never gone out of print,[216] and have been adapted continually for the screen since the invention of cinema,[217] with at least 200 motion pictures and TV adaptations based on Dickens's works documented.[218] Many of his works were adapted for the stage during his own lifetime – early productions included *The Haunted Man* which was performed in the West End's Adelphi Theatre in 1848 – and, as early as 1901, the British silent film *Scrooge, or, Marley's Ghost* was made by Walter R. Booth.[219] Contemporaries such as publisher Edward Lloyd cashed in on Dickens's popularity with cheap imitations of his novels, resulting in his own popular 'penny dreadfuls'.[220]

His 1843 novella *A Christmas Carol* remains especially popular and continues to inspire adaptations in every creative medium. *Oliver Twist* and *Great Expectations* are also frequently adapted and, like many of his novels, evoke images of early Victorian London. His 1859 novel *A Tale of Two Cities* (set in London and Paris) is his best-known work of historical fiction. The most famous celebrity of his era, he undertook, in response to public demand, a series of public reading tours in the later part of his career.[10] The term *Dickensian* is used to describe something that is reminiscent of Dickens and his writings, such as poor social or working conditions, or comically repulsive characters.[11][12]

Dickens was the most popular novelist of his time,[215] and remains one of the best-known and most-read of English authors. His works have never gone out of print,[216] and have been adapted continually for the screen since the invention of cinema,[217] with at least 200 motion pictures and TV adaptations based on Dickens's works documented.[218] Many of his works were adapted for the stage during his own lifetime – early productions included *The Haunted Man* which was performed in the West End's Adelphi Theatre in 1848 – and, as early as 1901, the British silent film *Scrooge, or, Marley's Ghost* was made by Walter R. Booth.[219] Contemporaries such as publisher Edward Lloyd cashed in on Dickens's popularity with cheap imitations of his novels, resulting in his own popular 'penny dreadfuls'.[220]

His 1859 novel *A Tale of Two Cities* (set in London and Paris) is his best-known work of historical fiction. The most famous celebrity of his era, he undertook, in response to public demand, a series of public reading tours in the later part of his career.[10] The term *Dickensian* is used to describe something that is reminiscent of Dickens and his writings, such as poor social or working conditions, or comically repulsive characters.[11][12]
